title: World Stock Market Recovery Gains Momentum
text:

Wed, Sep 9, 2015, 17:46 BST - UK Markets closed World Stock Market Recovery Gains Momentum By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News â€“ 8 minutes ago View Photo 

There has been a surge in world stock markets as bargain hunters snap up shares following the recent slump in values. 
The gains have been particularly strong in Japan, where the Nikkei closed 7.7% higher on Wednesday, boosted by renewed government promises of a cut to corporate tax rates. 
Analysts said it was the market's biggest one-day gain since 2008. 
In the previous session, the Nikkei had lost 2.4% and wiped out its year-to-date gain in the process but sentiment was lifted on Wednesday following strong sessions in the US and Europe. 
The recovery has also been felt across Asia, with China's Shanghai Composite up 2.3% having fallen more than 40% since mid-June amid turmoil over the slowdown in its economy - the second-largest in the world - and a lack of confidence in its reporting of the economic troubles. 
The FTSE 100 opened 1.8% higher at 6252 with miners adding some value, while travel stocks were lifted by a 25% increase in profit expectations from Ryanair which has, like rivals, benefited from wet UK summer weather and the effects of a strong pound. 
London's top-flight share index closed at 6229 - up 1.35%. 
Investor (Stockholm: INVE-A.ST - news ) mood has brightened in recent days as hopes have risen for more stimulus in China, while the Chinese authorities have also announced a shake-up of how GDP output is measured to bring it more into line with global standards. 
German trade data suggested Europe's biggest economy was shrugging off a weakening of demand, with exports hitting record highs in value terms in July. 
There has also been renewed hopes that the US Federal Reserve will hold off on raising interest rates next week. 
The World Bank was the latest institution to follow the European Central Bank and International Monetary Fund in suggesting it was too soon, arguing it would cause "panic and turmoil", especially in emerging markets. 
Angus Gluskie, managing director of White Funds Management, told the Reuters news agency: "With many markets having been sold off heavily over recent weeks, today's rally, like the US last night, represents a speculative bounce. 
"The market will remain susceptible to a return of negativity until we see signs of some improvement in the original causes of weakness, which were predominantly Chinese growth concerns (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) ."
